United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Substantive preparatory papers, pp. 48-278
			
 PDF (86.4 MB) 



Page 98


THE SECON'D QUEBEC CONFERENCE
ing. No official minutes of the meeting have been found, but informaa-
tion on the meeting is included in Hull, pp. 1608-1609; Stimson and
Bundy, pp. 569-570; Morgenthau material printed in Blum, pp. 359-
360, and Morgenthau Diary (Germany), vol. 1, pp. 524-528; and For-
eign Relations, The Conferences at Malta and Yalta, 1945, p. 161.
740.00119 EW/9-444
The President's Special Assistant (Hopkhirs) to the Secretary of State
 [WASHINGTON,] September 5, 1944.
 AMy Dmk MiR. SECRETARY: With minor reservations about language
which do not affect the intent of the document, "Suggested Recommen-
dations on Treatment of Germany from the Cabinet Committee for
the President',1 I approve of it.
 If there be agreement on policies, then it becomes of the utmost im-
portance for the proper Govermnent Officials to indicate how the poli-
cies in this document are to be implemented.
 Sincerely yours, HARRY L. HoPKiINS
 'Ante, p. 95.
Roosevelt Papers
 The Secretary of Wiar (Stirnson) to the President 1
 [WASHINGTON, September 5, 1944.]
 I have considered the paper entitled "Suggested Recommendations
on Treatment of Germany from the Cabinet Committee for the Presi-
denit", dated September 4th,2 submitted to the Committee by the Sec-
retary of State and have discussed it with my colleagues OIn the
Committee.
 With the exception of the last paragraph I find myself in agreement
with the principles stated therein and they are in conformity with
the lines upon which we have been proceeding in the War Department
in our directives to the Armed Forces.
 The last paragraph, however, is as follows:
 "h. The primary objectives of our economic policy are (1) the
standard of living of the German population shall be held down to
subsistence levels; (2) German economic position of power in Europe
must be eliminated; (3) German economic capacity must be converted
in such manner that it will be so dependent upon imports and exports
that Germany cannot by its own devices reconvert to war production".
'Sent to Hull for forwarding to the President. Stimson sent copies also to
Hopkins and Morgenthau. See Stimson and Bundy, p. 570.
'Ante, p. 95.
